Articles.Content:
Hi!

To be honest, this is less a direct question, but I would love to hear people's opinions on it.

I'm currently playing around with a collider mesh for the LK Lander, it's a really odd shape, which means high-poly colliders unfortunately.

So, how does this sound?

It's made of three mesh, to keep things convex.

Hull, 82 Polygons

![44dfaa1105.png](http://puu.sh/gfyDU/44dfaa1105.png)

Trunk, 34 Polygons

![db6dcdab11.png](http://puu.sh/gfyEZ/db6dcdab11.png)

Plate, 18 Polygons

![1c24f9ad86.png](http://puu.sh/gfyFQ/1c24f9ad86.png)

So, three meshes, total of **134 polygons**. ![:sealed:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_lipssealed.gif)

So I ask, how do other persons go about creating colliders for more "weird" shapes? What polycounts do you aim for? I know this is a very vague question, for that I apologise.

Thanks! ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
The station modules in FusTek have recesses, rings and cutouts, so I usually use a series of wedge-shaped colliders arranged in circles.

A single mesh collider object can have 255 (or maybe 256) faces, but you can have multiple mesh colliders (and multiple primitive colliders). All colliders must be convex, so your system as depicted must be a minimum of 3 mesh collider objects or it will be automagically simplified into a convex hull that I think will resemble a dried cat turd.

I don't expect that number of faces will pose a significant issue for anyone except the most abusive players, if you can make any of that out of primitives instead of mesh that'll help, but you'd need to sacrifice accuracy by quite a bit. With how large that capsule is I'd say the accuracy is worth the performance hit.

thanks!

Unity doesn't have a cylinder primitive. There's "box", "capsule" and "sphere"

>

Okay!

Those basic shapes, I've used in the past, I had it in mind they had some problems with "falling through the terrain", just my experience using them. But, I'll give them another look.

Thanks!
